Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 06:41PM flyrzfan wrote: You know, I almost wish I had never like him. It would make this that much easier. I've been defending him to others ragging on him about this affair because the story originated with the National Enquirer. They are not exactly known for top notch journalism. I am just so saddened and disheartened by this. THANK GOD he is not the presumptive nominee!!!!  I would never in a million years vote for him now and I was a huge fan before. All this time I though Elizabeth was so lucky to have such a caring and supportive husband. I admired the way she stood up and said she wanted him to run in spite of her medical condition. I think she is an amazing woman and after this news, I have more respect for her than ever. I hope whatever happens in her marriage, that she is happy and loved and at peace with her situation. Forgiveness is not easy and I suspect John was lucky enough to receive it once, but apparently did not appreciate it enough to not do it again. What ever Elizabeth decides, I"ll respect. As everyone in a long term relationship knows, leaving is easy ~ staying and working it out is the hard part. Please be gentle in your judgements, you never know if she is going to read these posts.

Posts.Content: flyrzfan wrote: hi all ~ I'm a "newbie" and in the process of trying to digest all the information I'm getting...I was diagnosed on Friday. When the Dr. who did the biopsy called I didn't get any more info other than the biopsy was positive for breast cancer. I scheduled my appt. w/surgeon two weeks out...which my family Dr. was ok with -until she got my biopsy report. Now she wants me find someone available sooner because my cancer is ER+, HER2+, indicitive of being invasive and had cancer cells in all 5 samples. So...my question is, if HER2+ cancers don't respond well to tamoxifin treatments...but ER+ positive ones do...what do you do if you are positive for both? Actually...I have a second question if that's ok....I am strongly considering masectomy (for personal reasons to long to explain here, it's more appealing than a less conservative route). What kind of recouperation time does that entail? I found information on everything BUT how long the average time to recover is...Thanks in advance for your help...this is the only place where I have found reassurance so far! Log in to post a reply

I just can't put two and two together on that abbreviation...

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 08:04AM flyrzfan wrote: oh anne, i am just sending you lov and supportt.....i knew nothing of nerve pain intil i wok up in the icu after my blm w/diep right after. when i woke up, i only had use of my pinkies....immediately my g/f massaged he helll out of right arm when she came in...after 3mdaysmit was,back 99%    the right arem, total different story....swollen, numb and no movement afer 2 days....occupational therapy got movement in pinky and ring....butthat was it....nerve medsdident come until follow up a week later (i was in tears begging them to take pain away). 1st one did not work....2nd one was lyrica....which now has pain down to a constant dull arthritic type pain which is bearable.index and thumb are still comletely numb, middle is partial numb. your post is first i have found on this subject...please. let me know if there is anything besides home massage and stress hand squeezers i cando at home to heal this. at moment i am blocke from oc therapy because i also had to have 2nd surgery for some necrosis that set in,,,,any aadvice is welcome....sorry i havenone on ur specific experience....

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 01:47AM flyrzfan wrote: hi ladies...hope this finds everone healing well and feeling good...the  surgery went perftect....we had a suprise for the dr in that the left breast filled with fluid as well the night before the surgery and since that nipple was still showing signs that it may/may not survive - we went all the way and removed both nipples and put drains back in on both sides. HUGE difference. taking out dead tissue,infection and putting drains in has made me feel so much better. i thank all of you for the well wishes and the prayers -they worked !  Tina...can you imagine, I tried so hard to finish watching game and fell asleep in like the last 10 seconds....when i saw the recap on espn the next day i realized i zonked at the last few seconds....how po'd was i? anyway...time for a break...best wishes to all.....bonnie

Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 03:02AM flyrzfan wrote: oh kathy ~ i am so glad to get to end of thread and read you are looking for another ps. good luck in search and dont stop until you find one you TRUST AND LIKE. i have not been well enough to post much since my blm on 4/10 -and hesitate to share complications because i dont want to freak out newbies, but these surgeries always come with risks and i can tell you, for what i am going through-having caring, patient and concerned doctors has been tremendous help! not only have they made me feel like thier only priority, they gave me personal cell phone numbers to call to expedite in case i develop any new symptoms -how awesome are they? the point, our lives and futures are in thier hands - make sure u pick one who appreciates that!! best of luck my friend. bonnie
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 07:46AM flyrzfan wrote: apple - I know where you are going with your question and there is no answer to it. yes, you can go into denial and hope faith and prayer will cure u of this disease. looking atyour pathology, yours is going to be aggressive. WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW NOW IS THIS - by ignoring this you are not going to carry on as if all is normal, and then one day just keel over. You will have weight loss, become sick easily, get to the point where you cant get out of bed to pee, so you pee the bed -and if ur lucky, someone cleans it up for you all the while telling you its ok -because they know you had no control over it. You will lose so much weight and age so fast that you will become unrecognizable to everyone, even your family. you will eventually need hospice or hospitalization in  the end so they can help you manage the agony known as death. does all this seem like a harsh reality check? sweetie, its meant to be. as hard as it is....u need to make a list of what you do now...and enlist help and get commitments from people to help you. yuo belong to a hurch -that is and will be a hugh resource for you....you have kids (lots) talk with them to explain what lies ahead and what they will need to do. trust me, my journey has tested me too -butyou can only fantasize about ignoring it....you cant really do it. i have taken this journey twice in the past 2 years with loved ones who ended up passing away in the way i described. oone had breast cancer, one had liver cancer. my friend with bc lived a longer, fuller life and in the end had a smoothr passing than my aunt who, by the time she was diagnosed -had no time to do anything about it. please call on friends and family and let go of what is not essential at this point in ur life...and let us know if we can help, suggest,or just listen....sending hugs ur way...bonnie
Posts.Title: can I give up? Appleg8 swimangel72

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 11:25AM flyrzfan wrote: It was quite by accident I found this thread but I'm so glad I did. I had no idea there were so many April surgery girls out there...I am having a blm w/diep recon on April 10th...all my prayers to the ladies who started today and the rest of us to follow this month...One step closer to putting it all behind us now!! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 11:48PM flyrzfan wrote: just wanted to check in on all the april ladies and see how everyone is making out ~ glad to hear all the great news for recoveries...i had some minor issues we are still working on (numbness in arms lasting longern than expected) but all in all everything went fabulous. i was out in 3 days, drains were out in 5 and i was up and walking/using bathroom 10 hours after surgery - recovery is relatively painless. Mostly, i just need to know when it's time to stop and take a nap. with these beautifuls days we have had here on east coast i learned hard way about over doing it...know better now. i hopw you all continue to improve and send my prayers out to those of you just begining this phase...i saw where some were looking for a list of what to do and such ~there is one on another thread -i think the before during and after threaD..."OTTER" posted it ...I wish i knew how to forward it here for you...it was invaluable. ie. baby wipes for cleaning up until u can shower, button up shirts and pull on pants, moving everthing down do you don't have to reach...i set up bed and bath downstairs so i didn't have to climb (this was big benefit)..and delegate anyhing you can to those who offer to help...i have and my friends have been fan-tastic about helping...also -STAY HYDRATED....DRINK more than you think you need...helps with recovery and bowels...trust me on this ... best wishes to all going in...bonnie
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2008 04:36AM flyrzfan wrote: sally-self centered fogs aree part of the deal...feel no regrets,we understand...thank you all for the hugs and prayers...wanted to share good news -kerry that gabapentin was tried but failed to wprk on nerve pain...however i am now on lyrica which has given me so much relief. mssherry - i so feel your pain an i hope and pray your problems turn around soon, please feel free to pm me and ask me anything u want....i do believe nothing is to personal at this point. once u havebeen on the receiving end of a fleet, its all an open book. best wishes and big hugs to all of you.....bonnie ps. still typing one handed but use of left hand is getting better....so, pardon typos :)
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2008 10:37AM flyrzfan wrote: hi ladies....short update with good and bad. new nerve med has allowed somuch exercising /therapy i am actually using some of the fingers on left hand to type - fingers are still numb but fact that they go to the key my brain tells them to means the path is there and i just need keep exerfising them. bad news is, infection is back with fever and all kinds of ass kicked feeling fun. the tissue has died and i will have surgery to remove it an all the infected area around it. most important thingnow is saiving the flap underneath from getting infected...so please say pyrayers they dont f up my other arm this time or it will be a reaaaaaly long time brfore i can up date and chyeck on everyones progress...saying prayers for all of u...even if im not typing i am thinking of my bc sisters and wishing them well...tk care, bonnie

Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 07:41AM flyrzfan wrote: hi kathy ~ thanks for the note, i totally ubderstand your point and will give more detail on the board for everyone to seethe downside to these surgeries...also, pardon typos now but at this time i still have only functional use of one hand and alll those corrections are too time consuming :)  the hand issue i am told is a side effect of the position my arm was in during surgery combined wth lenght of surgery -in total almost 12 hours (blm with diep immediately after ). when i first woke up i in icu i only had feeling in pinkies on each side...all iv's were in left arm...so when gf/mother/sister came they massaged right arm alot and after 3 days that one was back 100%. in icu (i was in icu after surgery for first 2 days so i could be monitored round clock) occupational therapy came to work on left side but only managed to get ring finger to respond-nothing with index,middle or thumb. the nerve pain has at times left me just crying for lack of any relief -they gave me nerve meds (little to no response from my system with/for them). i use valium for muscle spasms i get in bicep from this and dilauded which helps bring pain down to tolerable level 80% of time and helps me sleep 4-5 hours at a time. therapy and family massages have gotten me movement now in all fingers 2 weeks into it, pain is of course at its worst after exercises are done. 2nd complication -although on the level of pain scale, the much easier of the two to deal wtih is the tissue survival and infections. see, i had nipple sparing diep recon immediately after my bilateral. the right nipple skin has died, but at this time does appear to have enough healthy skin underneath to still pull through and recover -there is also minor infection on this side. my left nipple at this time is much more infected and is not showing the same signs of having enough healthy tissue under neath to survive which would mean a second surgery to remove it and the infected skin. we are day by day on the outcome on this right now. since the infection set in i have been getting backed up with fluids so they are also draining me at each visit -currently every other day...through it all my team has been wonderful and while this sucks completely, they are able to use these setbacks to look at what they can/cant do for future women who have this surgery...the fact they are learning somehow makes it easier -since what we figure out now may help someone else not go through it. in the mean time its a hard road i would not wish on anyone so your right, women need to know the pitfalls too so they can make an informed decision for themselves...for anyone on the fence,take this in context with what your body is like. my biggest hesitation in making decision is i knew my body is weird, i always manage to fall into the "1% of patients will experience th following coplications" -but i prayed just this once that would not be the case for me....i also knew if it was i would be able to handle the recovery regardless. i have bad days, i have very very bad days, but i also have a few good ones so you just keep going. dont let my worst case scenario scare you off, just let you own heart and body be your guide. best wishes to all....

Posts.Title: Help from more senior chemo girl (ac) flyrzfan Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: flyrzfan wrote: Hi girls...looking for help or reassurance from someone with a few tx's under the belt? I had my first tx of A/Con 6/5 - bad se's x 5 days...nausea, 'rrreaha, fatigue mostly. SE's went away yesterday just like that except for (of course)  rrreaha.  Today it's been every 2-3 hours and my stomach -which hurt a bit this am (I had no fever and didn't really feel sick) before I went to work....by lunch, I feel very nauseaus again and my tummy (liver area) hurts pretty good. I am one week out from tx. Left msg earlier with onc re: normal? Have not heard back and have to now go to PT... is it normal to feel better then feel crappy again? Could my WBC just be getting low causing this funk? I tend not to worry enough (read: wait stuff out) but know now is not time to play. If I need to I can call onc on call @ hosp. later but wanted to know if this experience was just part of the A/C ride? Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 06:49AM flyrzfan wrote: oh the fear that binds us...Sugarpea, the ladies are right. There is no way for you to know for sure what is going on with YOUR body ~ until you see a doctor. I went to the doctor with a cold that wouldn't go away, what turned out to be pink eye, and pain in my arm pit. Two weeks later I am getting a lumpectomy and lymph node biopsy having been diagnosed with Breast Cancer. I am still trying to comprehend how I got from point A to point B, but the simple fact is ~ when something is wrong with your body, go to the doctor. Your best chance at staying healthy, is to consult a Dr. when something doesn't feel right. From what you have said (and not said) you have something that doesn't "feel" right. Please, take a deep breath and pick up the phone. You could be worrying yourself sick for nothing more than an underlying infection that is causing your problem. My prayers are with you, not only for your health and well being ~ but you to have the strength to overcome the fear of making the call... Bonnie

Posts.Title: PET Results are In! webwriter apple

Posts.Content: May 18, 2008 07:21PM flyrzfan wrote: hi all - sorry to leave u all hanging out there...i finally got my chemo scedule and start date - may 29th...so im sqeaking in on the may class. thank u all for your posts on how u r doing so far....good info -especially since i didnt get the chemo reg i expected because of my pathology and oconodx score. im doing ac 2weeks x4, taxol/herceptin  weekly x12, herceptin for 40 weeks after that along with tamoxifen x5 yrs. i was told i would get neulasta with each chemo tx - still trying to find a way out of that part so if anyone has any alternatives i can take to my onco, im listening! pepper - 1st on the multiple post thing....no worries, been there too.....on the fluid - here is my experience (and its a colorful one so far), if ur fluid build up becomes painful or inhibits ur normal movement, it's time to go in for a drain off. they are relatively painless (slight sting) i have had six and from looks of it will be calling tomorrow for another. ive had 2 surgeries, drains pulled when build up stopped -only to have pockets build up in other areas. some have not been bothersome and faded when i was able to move around more...some dont go on their own but in my experience, i only go for drain if they are painful - in the way - or dont go down after a week or so. check w/ur ps to ask what he is comfortable with u doing....its a sucky but not life threatening side effect that can be managed quickly and easily... best wishes to you all rcving tx this week....have busy week w/muga, port insert, acupuncurist and trying to make a plan to return to work before i run out of leave... peace to all - soon to be bald and walking around that way...not the first time but hoping it's the last!!!! bonnie
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: May 19, 2008 08:16AM flyrzfan wrote: Adrienne ~ its the side effects mostly - especially the bone/muscle pain. Already have peripheral neuropathy in left arm and some days can barely handle that pain -and that is with the pain meds i am already on. That being said, after reading a few other posts about wbc dropping dangerously low after 1st tx, I decided to deal with whatever Neulasta brings me. I am highly susceptible to infection and get them on average 6x's a year - for everything imaginable - so, Neulasta it is. Thanks for your input...it's appreciated...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: May 20, 2008 09:26AM flyrzfan wrote: hi ladies...i hope everyone has great SE free day....I am starting my day with a fake it until you make it attitude so please, if ur day has started out yucky too - join me! my mantra now is - "i have no choice but to keep going or quit and let the cancer kill me" - I won't be in the May chemo class afterall - my oncono called yesterday and informed me my blood work shows i am anemic and my liver levels are "high" so i have to back off chemo until i get an mri and work on the anemia...wth?  oh well, my best wishes to all of u coping with it this month...bonnie

Everything you're hearing is spot on, like Marin said - the beginning is the worst, you do settle in and fit it into your day to day life and all your feelings are what most of us went through when we first found out...I'm sorry you have to go through it but I'm glad you found this website. It's been a godsend for all of us on it. Best of luck to you...come here often, someone can always help! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Ok, so I have cancer emath jdg1

Posts.Content: May 9, 2008 04:50AM flyrzfan wrote: hi ladies ~ i may or may not be joining you for may chemo, it depends on what other tests if any my ocono wants. our first mtg is next wednesday. i had my tissue sent out for ocono type testing and that will play a large roll in what i do and for how long i do it. i am told the min would be 4 weeks of tc followed by hormones (5yrs) and herceptin(1yr)....and thats if i get a good score. love it. my hat is off to to ladies doing this with children in the mix.....i just cant imagine......happy mothers day -not the best of circumstances, but amazing that you will celebrate in spite of, or because of -the battle you face. bonnie
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 04:38PM flyrzfan wrote: Leeayn ~ I'm right there with you...I was diagnosed on 3/21/08 and I'm through with my chemo treatments and feeling like an old timer myself reading all the new people posting. For the newbies: I'm so sorry you are all going through this. I hope some day there will be a "final class" but for now, I'm so glad you found this forum. I think every cancer center/onc should recommend it to every woman being diagnosed. It's the one place I can come to connect, vent, find answers, get a shoulder, recieve comfort...and give back. Everything about it sucks, regardless of your stage, pathology, treatment, etc. Just know, you are not alone, you will get through it and every day they are getting closer to a cure. Hugs to all of you, stay with us and ask lots of questions!

Posts.Title: Deb C Update nosurrender LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 08:36PM flyrzfan wrote: Amber, I've not "met" you on these boards before but I read your post earlier today and was very touched by it. I'm neither stage IV nor a mother so I can't even pretend to know what you are going through. I can only tell you that 2 years ago I lost my best friend to this darn disease. Back then I didn't realize how much I didn't know about the treatments, the toll, the fight. When my friend called me to tell me she had decided to stop treatment, I was devastated. I felt like she was quitting on all of us that loved her. I of course, did not say that to her. I outwardly supported her and loved and held her until the end. But inside, I was heartbroken she didn't have it in her to fight...because I was going to miss her so, SO much. Even now, writing this...it breaks my heart all over again that she isn't here. But I now understand it so much more. Going through the past 7 months of my own cancer has given me a much deeper appreciation for what it took for her to say "enough is enough" and appreciate how brave she was. I am so glad to read you are doing better, I am so glad you had this forum where you could scream and cry - and have people here who understood, didn't judge, listened. Thank you for reaching out. No matter which road you had taken, you would have received the support you so obviously deserved. I love this "place"!
